captions.text:
Magic mushrooms: we know what they do - but
do we know how they work?

Hey guys, Tara here for Dnews - and you know
what fascinates me the most about science?

The fact that we're still learning new information
on things that have been around for thousands
of years.

Take psychedelic mushrooms, or Psilocybin
mushrooms. These have been around since the

prehistoric times. There's even a theory,
called the Stoned Ape Theory, which proposes

that humans evolved from early primates through
the use of psychedelic mushrooms. They've

been used in religious ceremonies all over
the world for centuries, and it's suggested

that the use of mushrooms and other psychedelic
drugs, are what formed the basis of modern
religion.

Today, people use them mostly recreationally
- and while the effects of mushrooms are pretty

well-known, what's NOT well-known - is how
they actually work. Until now.

A new study, published in Human Brain Mapping,
finds that psilocybin - the active chemical

in psychedelic mushrooms - is closely tied
to the parts of our brains that help us dream.

Now logically, this makes sense. Psychedelic
drugs are notorious for transporting users

into a heightened state of consciousness - which
explains why they're often used in a spiritual
context.

The part of our brains that get activated
during dream sleep - are tied to the brain's

ancient emotion system. And when someone takes
psychedelic drugs, that area of the brain

becomes uninhibited - so their emotions seem
to get "louder."

What's interesting, is that the ego system
- the part of brain that gives us our sense

of self - actually gets quieter and more disjointed,
under the effects of psychedelics. So it's

believed that the "quieting" of that ego system
- is what allows our emotional system to become

louder.
According to the author of the study, Dr.

Robin Carhart-Harris, psychedelics cause "ego
dissolution" - meaning they temporarily diminish

one's sense of having a firm and enduring
personality. At the same time, they widen

the breadth of associations made throughout
the brain - which is what enhances our creativity,

and causes that state of "expanded" consciousness.
That also explains why they're sometimes used

in psychotherapy. Because they help patients
facilitate an emotional release.

Speaking of emotional releases, I'm sure many
of you heard the news this week - about Hobby

Lobby and the Supreme Court Ruling allowing
them to deny contraception coverage for their

employees. At the risk of alienating half
of our audience, I will keep my opinions to

myself on this one - BUT I wanna remind everyone
that we have a new show called Test Tube - hosted

by Trace and myself - that's a lot like Dnews,
but focused more on current events. We've

got a new episode up, where Trace talks all
about the Hobby Lobby ruling - and what it

means for America. So if you're looking to
learn more about that situation, we'd love

it if you checked out the show. You can find
that episode - and many more - over at youtube.com/TestTubeNetwork.

In the meantime, if you've got any questions,
comments, anything you wanna say about this

episode - or psychedelic drugs in general
- leave em in the comments below. Otherwise,
thanks for watching!

title: How Do Magic Mushrooms Expand Your Mind?

comments.author: RagingBubuli

comments.text:
I think mushrooms should be legalized and I have tried them myself much to 
my enjoyment, but this video has some biased language. In a science context 
like DNews, the terms "heightened consciousness" and "expanded 
consciousness" are too biased in favor of the drug. Surely some people have 
taken shrooms and continued to be petty, racist, consumerist, etc while 
tripping. Also, the idea of the "stoned caveman" is Terrence McKenna's 
hypothesis, and as likable and smart as that guy was, he was still a 
massive shoveler of pseudoscience. Wikipedia's article on him explains the 
criticism of this idea here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terence_McKenna#.22Stoned_ape.22_theory_of_human_evolution
...and I don't see why a science outlet like DNews would mention a cockeyed 
idea like this as if it's serious science. ﻿

comments.text:
+Ryance85 We the present day humans evolving from apes eating shit? No, 
that's crazy; we must've been poofed into existence by a magic man in a 
book with talking snakes, giants, unicorns & dragons (I'm sure the author 
wasn't ingesting plants rich in DMT which were growing locally at the time 
nearby or eating mushrooms). If it's the mushrooms you're poking fun at & 
not the evolution, then my question to you is why is it so hard to believe 
that nature evolved symbiotically in relation to us? A lot of plants that 
we eat evolved this way; we have a cannabinoid system in our body that 
mimics cannabis for example. Psilocybin is empathy-enhancing 
creativity-enhancing nootropic if used correctly; when used incorrectly I 
think it is the progenitor of lunacy & religion.﻿

know."

comments.author: Luxord Faith

comments.text:
any statistical data as to how ego dissolution affects different

comments.author: bergweg

comments.text:
"transports people into a heightened state of consciousness..."  Don't you 
mean lowered state of consciousness?  I mean,  when you are hallucinating 
you are clearly not experiencing the same reality as the rest of us.  Sure 
this can lead to creative thought,  but is it really a heightened state of 
consciousness?﻿
comments.author: Judicial78

comments.text: Not like our observation is objective...
comments.author: mouwersor

comments.text:
It definitely is. You're not really hallucinating. You don't actually see 
inanimate objects. You see colors and trails and the walls rippling and 
morphing. All of this is just a side effect the heightened state of 
consciousness is what you're thinking and what you learn from your feelings 
and thoughts. You'd be surprised until you do them just how important your 
ego is, no matter who you are.
comments.author: Alex Al

comments.text:
Vote Libertarian. Once we end this 2 party system we can begin to change 
this country for the better. No parties is the better option, so there is 
no bandwagoning but until then...LIBERTARIAN.

Cool info on mushrooms, if anyone is interested in having a psychedelic 
experience I would recommend Changa. 30 mins long and lot more lucidity 
compared to the new world you are thrown in with shrooms.﻿

comments.text: That guy was shaking while sleeping!﻿

comments.text:
What a load of bullcrap. The way shrooms expand your mind is by taking you

of the universe in a understandable foreign language by flapping its 
bellybuttons. I kid u not!﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Alex Al

comments.text:
I've been learning a lot of stuff in one of my Psych classes, and from what 
I've seen there is no measurable/noticeable boost to creativity or 
knowledge with the use of such psychedelics. Apparently you feel like 
you're being really creative while in reality you're pretty much the same 
without it.﻿
comments.author: Dhruv B

comments.text:
Perhaps mushroom discussed here is similar to what I tried several years 
ago. They said this is not a drugs and legal. Yeah... First it feels so 
weird then 30 minutes later everything around me became very funny and 
makes me can't stop LOL...
Don't wanna try that shit again.. Ever!!!﻿

comments.text:
